description: From Middle English chalk, chalke, from Old English ċealc, from Proto-West Germanic *kalk, borrowed from Latin calx (“limestone”), again borrowed from Ancient Greek χάλιξ (khálix, “pebble”). Doublet of calx and cauk.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A soft, white, powdery limestone (calcium carbonate, CaCO3).
examples: chalk cliffs are not recommended for climbing

entries.meaning: (countable) A piece of chalk, or nowadays processed compressed gypsum (calcium sulfate, CaSO4), that is used for drawing and for writing on a blackboard (chalkboard).
examples: the chalk used to write on the blackboard makes a squeaky sound

entries.meaning: (uncountable, climbing, gymnastics) A white powdery substance used to prevent hands slipping from holds when climbing, or losing grip in weight-lifting or gymnastics, sometimes but not always limestone-chalk, often magnesium carbonate (MgCO3).
examples: when working out your next move, it's a good idea to get some more chalk from the bag

entries.meaning: (US, military, countable) A platoon-sized group of airborne soldiers.
(US, sports, chiefly basketball, horseracing) The favorite in a sporting event.
(US, sports, chiefly basketball) The prediction that there will be no upsets, and the favored competitor will win.

verbs.description: chalk (third-person singular simple present chalks, present participle chalking, simple past and past participle chalked)

entries.meaning: To apply chalk to anything, such as the tip of a billiard cue.
To record something, as on a blackboard, using chalk.
To use powdered chalk to mark the lines on a playing field.
(figuratively) To record a score or event, as if on a chalkboard.
To make white, as if with chalk; to make pale; to bleach.
examples: Let a bleak paleness chalk the door.
